description: From Middle French malléable, borrowed from Late Latin malleābilis, derived from Latin malleāre (“to hammer”), from malleus (“hammer”), from Proto-Indo-European *mal-ni- (“crushing”), an extended variant of *melh₂- (“crush, grind”).

adjectives.description: malleable (comparative more malleable, superlative most malleable)

entries.meaning: Able to be hammered into thin sheets; capable of being extended or shaped by beating with a hammer, or by the pressure of rollers.

examples: My opinion on the subject is malleable.

entries.meaning: (cryptography, of an algorithm) in which an adversary can alter a ciphertext such that it decrypts to a related plaintext
